content.description:
This is a fantastic, bolted, boulder problem.  Enjoy 25 feet of overhanging climbing on sharp crimps to a jug that gains the slab.  Save some gas for the last few moves leading to the jug.  Another 15 feet of casual climbing gets you to the shared anchors for

Top Soil

.  Incidentally, the shared anchors allow for easy access to try this route on top rope.
content.protection:
5 bolts, fixed biners on the shared anchors of

Top Soil

.
content.location: On Haus Rock, this is on the right side of the south face, just left of the dihedral.

content.description: This has great, pumpy climb with a little stemming.  Start at the first bolt up the crack to bomber holds.  The first bolt is a bit of a runout but should not be a problem.
content.protection: 4 draws and a rope.
content.location: This is the farthest right climb (well now second farthest right) on the south side.

content.description: This is a short climb with some fun moves.  It has a thin slab between the second and third bolts.  The rock gets a bit dirty towards the top.  There is a good standing shelf at top to rest and take down gear.
content.protection: Rope and 5 draws + 2 anchors.
content.location: This is on the far west end of Haus next to Little Haus.

content.description: This has fun moves, is well-protected, and and is another good warm-up.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is to the left of

Little Squirt

and to the right of

Dirty Love

.

climbs.name: Susie Seka's Short, Yet So Seductive, Little, Flakey Arete

content.description:
Follow an easy arete with a low first bolt to a roof. Surmount the roof, then head towards the anchors on

Not Lichen This

.
content.protection: 5 bolts.
content.location:
This ascends the arete to the left of

Not Lichen This

.

content.description:
This is one of the better slab climbs on Haus Rock.  There are some pockets that you will be able to get one to two fingers in as well.

If you are looking to top rope, this climb you may set up on "

Feet Do Not Fail Me Now

" (5.8) or just walk up the left side of Haus.

If it rains a day or two before you climb Haus, check the rock midway up for wet spots.  This particular climb seems to stay wetter than the others on Haus.
content.protection: 7 draws and a rope.
content.location:
This is directly to the right of "

Feet Do Not Fail Me Now

".

content.description:
Start right of the

Crystal Ball

direct start and climb 3 bolts before merging with

Crystal Ball

.  Word on the street is that it's quite good.  As with

Crystal Ball

, avoid shameful grabbing of the chains, and you earn a gold star if you do a few extra moves to the jug above the chains.
content.protection: 5 bolts and fixed carabiners on chains for anchors.
content.location:
This is on Haus Rock's southside, right of

Crystal Ball

.  It is not to be confused with the

Crystal Ball

direct start.

content.description:
The bolt line just right of Top Soil. It has long moves on fragile feeling jugs. They haven't broken yet, so they're probably ok.

Climb up and over the ledge past the 3rd clip to two anchors on the slab above. It's probably in your rope's best interest to clean this route on rappel.  It is a bit dirty, but good, pumpy moves that are all there if you can find your balance.
content.protection: 4 draws some anchors and a rope.
content.location:
This is located to the right of

Top Soil

making this the new furthest right climb on the south side of Haus.

content.description: This is a climb past the small overhang to crimpy slab the rest of the way up. Tight shoes and strong finger tips are helpful.
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts and a rope.
content.location:
It is to the right of

The Spine

.

climbs.name: Proppa Toppa
climbs.fa: Eric De Caria, later climbed and named by T. Lanzano

content.description:
Climb the hard opening boulder problem on

Burning Down the Haus

. Move left to join

Sky Pilot

at its second bolt, then finish as per

Sky Pilot

/

Crystal Ball

.

It's a link-up but a good link-up. The name was suggested by Ted, but Eric may have a different name for it, if he named it.
content.protection: 5 bolts to Mussy hooks. Preclip bolt 1.
content.location:
Start on

Burning Down the Haus

.

content.description:
This variation is named after my wife (JK), or the two routes it starts and finishes on. Start on the

Crystal Ball

undercling, at the 2nd bolt head directly right through the first bolt on crystal ball direct and up and right into the first bolt on

Sky Pilot

. Take a deep breath and finish up on

Chainsaw

. This line provides around 70 feet of climbing on a 50 foot wall.
content.protection:
In the name of safety and less rope drag, I began the route with the first bolt on

Sky Pilot

and the two previous bolts directly left pre-clipped. Back clean the route for two bolts, pass 1st bolt on

Sky Pilot

, then lead the rest of the route. The belayer stands on the boulder. Bring 6-7 draws and a red Camalot. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
Start on

Crystal Ball

and finish on

Chainsaw

.

content.description:
The crux is on the upper slab.

Per

percious

: pull up into a large dish below the large s-shaped crack. Some juggy dihedral moves lead to some thin face climbing and the finish.
content.protection:
This shares anchors with

Hostile Krainzover

.
content.location:
It is left of

Hostile Krainzover

.

content.description: This is a fun route and not usually busy like some of the other climbs on Haus.  The first bolt is easily accessible but the second bolt takes some balance.  The rest of the climb is a nice pace.
content.protection: 4 draws and a rope to a set of chains.
content.location:
This route starts directly to the left of

Lichen This

.

content.description:
This is a great warm up climb on Haus. There are some tricky looking sections on the way up.  At the top, there is a small overhang.

You will need to set up a top rope on this climb.  To do this, you will have to walk around to the left of this climb and hike up the side of Haus Rock till you reach the first set of chains.

Just below the chains is a nice ledge where one can also learn to rappel.
content.protection:
Rope to chains.

It has now been bolted.
content.location: This is the leftmost climb on the Eastern side of Haus.

climbs.name: Macho Picasso
climbs.fa: J. Sjong, bolted by John Sore

content.description: This is a beautiful line that packs quite a wallop.  Climb a short overhang to a burly dyno.  One more move gets you to a bomber jug.  Rest up, because then the route gets hard.
content.protection: 4 bolts, one of which has a fixed draw on it.
content.location:
This is on Haus Rock's south side, left of

Crystal Ball

.

content.description: This is a fun climb, everything is really obvious and typical of 5.6 climbing.  It is a good warm-up.
content.protection: Three bolts to two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the first route on the far right side of the North side of Haus Rock.

content.description:
This is a 4 bolt line to two anchors with rings. It is short but a great pumpy climb.

Eds. note: this information was originally submitted as an area, but it appears to be a specific route.  Thus, the information was preserved, but it was changed in format.  The FA, length

etc.

area unknown to the editor.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This climb is on the far west of the rock towards Keystone.

content.description: Great warm up climb.  Start under a overhang and can either choose to go over or around (need good feet for this part).  One of the longer climbs on the north side.  This climb gets morning sun.
content.protection: 7 draws or so and a rope.
content.location: The second most left bolted climb on the North side of Haus.

content.description: The first bolt is about 10' off the ground up a large crack to small overhang.  The rest of the 4 bolts lead you up a thin slab to two anchors with rings.  This climb can also be set up on top rope.
content.protection: 5 draws and a rope.
content.location:
This is directly to the left of "

Feet Do Not Fail Me Now

."

content.description: Half and Half is a fun route that could’ve probably just been fully bolted. I led it without any trad gear, but I would not recommend this at all (SCARY). The lower section ends with some nice slab climbing.
content.protection: Small cams, nuts, and 3 bolts for the upper section to some old coldshuts.
content.location:
It is between the two 11s (

Throwin' The Drool Again

and

Dink

).

climbs.name: Feet Do Not Fail Me Now

content.description:
Feet Do Not Fail Me Now is the left of two routes that ascend the largest expanse of stone on the Haus Rock slab.  It's one of the better routes at Haus Rock.  Begin on some white rock just right of the wide, angling crack and follow the line of clips up and left.  It's easiest to move slightly left at the last bolt, then hand traverse the lip to the anchors.

A toprope can be easily set up by scrambling up the left side of the rock.
content.protection: 8 bolts to anchors.

content.description:
This is a good steady 5.8 climb up 5 bolts to an anchor with chains.  You can stop there and borrow a second set of chains from "

They Call Me Shorty

" or climb up the right of the arete to a second set of chains.
content.protection:
5 or seven bolts.

Per

Jacob Deneault

: the anchor completely gone. One bolt is ripped out, and the other is just a stud.
content.location:
It is right of

Flakin' Out

.

content.description: A higball V0 gets you to the first bolt, a V2 gets you to the second bolt, and over the roof.  Runout 5.7 climbing finishes the route.  The moves to the first bolt are easy, but falling would be very bad.
content.protection: 2 bolts, but really that's all you need.
content.location: On the left side of Haus Rock's southern face, this climbs through a short roof.

content.description: Start low and climb out the overhanging bulge on crimps and an odd pinch.  Expect to get peculiar looks from everyone top-roping on the slab side of Haus rock
content.protection: Two pads, one for the inconveniently located rock under the opening moves, and one for behind the sloping rock.
content.location: This problem is on the obvious boulder on the north side of Haus Rock.

content.description: On the South side of Haus Rock, start on an undercling and climb an obvious, diagonal seam up and right to hanging chains.  An optional and exciting move to a jug past the chains adds a little bit of spice to the experience.  Grabbing the chains to clip the anchors is bad form.  There is also a direct start a few feet to the right of the traditional start which also goes at 12b but is a bit easier.
content.protection: Fixed chains at the top.
content.location: This is on the South side of Haus Rock.

content.description:
Start on

Sky Pilot

on top of the boulder right of Crystal Ball Direct. Clip the first bolt on

Sky Pilot

and trend up and right on underclings and edges clipping 2 more bolts to a ledge. Traverse right into the big crack, plug some gear, and cruise up and back left to a two bolt anchor. The crux is between the 2nd and 3rd bolts.
content.protection: 3 draws, gear to 1.5", 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is on the South side of Haus, use the same start as

Sky Pilot

.

content.description:
Start same as "

Crystal Ball

," move left at second bolt. It is pretty much hard to the top.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location: It is on the South face of Haus Rock.

content.description:
Start about 10 feet to the left of

Torqued Blow

, and climb up and left to a high 1st bolt. A powerful 12+ sequence angles up and right to a seam where you can get a quick rest by the 3rd bolt before pulling some reachy and thin crux moves on the blank face past 2 more bolts until you reach the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor, and a stick clip for 1st bolt.
content.location:
This route starts about 10 feet left of

Torqued Blow

and just to the right of the small boulder and to the right of

Sky Pilot

.
